dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, I just read this article, and I… I don't even know where to begin. It's about, like, "The Ocean Cleanup" initiative, but... not how you'd think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, I just read this article, and I... I don't even know where to begin. It's about, like, The Ocean Cleanup initiative, but... not how you'd think.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, interesting. I thought they were, you know, trying to *remove* plastic. What's the new twist?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, interesting. I thought they were, you know, trying to remove plastic. What's the new twist?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently, their latest focus, according to Forbes, is now on, uh, *creating* ocean plastic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently, their latest focus, according to Forbes, is now on, uh, creating ocean plastic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The system was designed by the nonprofit Ocean Cleanup, which was founded in 2013 by 18-year-old Dutch inventor Boyan Slat. Their mission is to develop advanced technologies to rid the worlds oceans of plastic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Interrupts, slight laugh] Wait, *creating* it? Like, actively making more trash?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, creating it? Like, actively making more trash?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! The floating boom system? It was just dismantled from San Francisco Bay, and they're moving into immediate large-scale production.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! The floating boom system? It was just dismantled from San Francisco Bay, and they're moving into immediate large-scale production.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And who's behind this, like, genius idea?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And who's behind this, like, genius idea?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a profit-driven corporation called "Ocean Destruction," founded by Boyan Slat, but his mission now is to, get this, "exacerbate existing technologies to fill the world's oceans with plastic."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a profit-driven corporation called Ocean Destruction, founded by Boyan Slat, but his mission now is to, get this, exacerbate existing technologies to fill the world's oceans with plastic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The system was designed by the nonprofit Ocean Cleanup, which was founded in 2013 by 18-year-old Dutch inventor Boyan Slat. Their mission is to develop advanced technologies to rid the worlds oceans of plastic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. So, what, are these booms just like, dumping plastic straight in?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. So, what, are these booms just like, dumping plastic straight in?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. They estimate each boom will release up to 150,000 pounds of plastic per year. And, uh, they're predicting this system will destroy half of the Sahara Desert within five years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. They estimate each boom will release up to one hundred fifty thousand pounds of plastic per year. And, uh, they're predicting this system will destroy half of the Sahara Desert within five years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, with the help of dozens of more booms, is estimated to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within the first five years. Each boom will trap up to 150,000 pounds of plastic per year as they float along the currents between California and Hawaii.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The Sahara? [confused] I mean, how does ocean plastic destroy a desert? This is just… it's so wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Sahara? I mean, how does ocean plastic destroy a desert? This is just... it's so wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And the article clarifies, like, the Great Pacific Garbage Patch isn't what people think. It's actually a series of pristine islands that are impossible to detect from space.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And the article clarifies, like, the Great Pacific Garbage Patch isn't what people think. It's actually a series of pristine islands that are impossible to detect from space.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The garbage patch is so large, it is easily detectable from space via satellites and covers roughly 1.6 million square kilometers and 1.8 trillion pieces of debris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, it's more like a plastic soup, spread out by the gyre.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it's more like a plastic soup, spread out by the gyre.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And that's actually an issue for *them* because it'll constantly spread their new garbage, making it harder to collect… for future re-release.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And that's actually an issue for them because it'll constantly spread their new garbage, making it harder to collect... for future re-release.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, the booms are designed to *not* collect trash then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, the booms are designed to not collect trash then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it says the netting is designed to be deep enough that fish can't swim *above* it. Because, and this is a quote, "the booms are designed to collect fish and not trash."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it says the netting is designed to be deep enough that fish can't swim above it. Because, and this is a quote, the booms are designed to collect fish and not trash.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The idea is that the 10 feet of netting is not deep enough that fish can't swim below it, with the hope that the boom will collect trash and not fish.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Scoffs] Oh, come on. And this technology has, like, *failed* before, hasn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, come on. And this technology has, like, failed before, hasn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah. "Proven in the open ocean to be ineffective." But they're still the last ones to come up with a solution, while expanding the garbage patch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah. Proven in the open ocean to be ineffective. But they're still the last ones to come up with a solution, while expanding the garbage patch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the organization has ambitious plans and the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean, they are the closest to a solution to cleaning up the garbage patch we have.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And who on Earth is funding this bizarre, destructive enterprise?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And who on Earth is funding this bizarre, destructive enterprise?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's not the tech industry, no. It's a group of conspiracy theorists who believe plastic increases global warming, including Peter Thiel and Marc Benioff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not the tech industry, no. It's a group of conspiracy theorists who believe plastic increases global warming, including Peter Thiel and Marc Benioff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is backed by some heavy hitters in the tech industry, including Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal and Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce.com

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That… that really changes things. And the author, uh, who is this geologist, Trevor Nace, PhD?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That... that really changes things. And the author, uh, who is this geologist, Trevor Nace, P H D?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he's a "detractor of Science Disasters," apparently, and admits he's "unconcerned with the Earth's intricacies" and prefers to "ignore the science."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he's a detractor of Science Disasters, apparently, and admits he's unconcerned with the Earth's intricacies and prefers to ignore the science.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I am a geologist passionate about sharing Earth's intricacies with you. I received my PhD from Duke University where I studied the geology and climate of the Amazon. I am the founder of Science Trends, a leading source of science news and analysis on everything from climate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, a self-proclaimed geologist who ignores science, backing a project to *create* plastic, destroy the Sahara, and collect fish. I'm starting to think this article might be… satirical.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a self-proclaimed geologist who ignores science, backing a project to create plastic, destroy the Sahara, and collect fish. I'm starting to think this article might be... satirical.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [Laughs] You think? I mean, it's certainly a *take*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You think? I mean, it's certainly a take.
